title: 108_hr3250
content: The "Child Nutrition Improvement Act of 2003" may be cited as the Act. It addresses the consumption of milk in schools. The "Child Nutrition Improvement Act of 2003" addresses the consumption of milk in schools, amending Section 9(a) of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to require schools to offer students a variety of flavored and unflavored milk options. The "Child Nutrition Improvement Act of 2003" requires schools to offer a variety of milk options to students, including flavored and unflavored milk. The Act also prohibits restrictions on the sale or marketing of milk products on school premises or at school-sponsored events. This amendment applies to agreements or contracts entered into after the Act's enactment date. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to establish a program encouraging schools to increase milk consumption by improving the nutritional value of meals. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to establish a program encouraging schools to increase milk consumption by improving the nutritional value of meals. The program aims to increase fluid milk consumption in schools through approved plans with criteria set by the Secretary. Plans may include goals for increasing milk consumption and improving accessibility and promotion of milk. The program aims to improve fluid milk consumption in schools by enhancing the nutritional value of meals and promoting milk through tailored plans that consider the school's population and location, as well as packaging, flavor variety, and merchandising strategies. The program aims to improve fluid milk consumption in schools by increasing standard serving sizes for middle and high schools. The Secretary will establish criteria for plans, considering relevant research and consulting with various groups. Reimbursement rates and incentives will be provided for administering the program. The Secretary will annually provide reimbursement rates and incentives for free and reduced price meals to reflect the additional costs of increasing fluid milk consumption in schools. Rates will range from 2 to 10 cents per meal, with variations based on adoption of criteria established by the Secretary. Improved nutrition and physical activity levels of children will be addressed. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include a program for improving the nutrition and physical activity levels of children through healthy school environment programs. Grants will be provided to schools implementing these programs. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with nonprofit organizations, educational institutions, and other entities to provide grants for healthy school environment programs. The Secretary can accept funds from these entities solely for the program's implementation.
